unnormalised: ## Donating and Feeling Good - Let's Talk ₹s and Karma!
normalised: ## Donating and Feeling Good - Let's Talk Rupees and Karma!

unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, I was just thinking about something super important – giving back. You know, doing a little good in the world. And let’s be real, a lot of that involves…money. Or, as we say here in India, *rupees*!
normalised: Hey everyone! So, I was just thinking about something super important – giving back. You know, doing a little good in the world. And let’s be real, a lot of that involves…money. Or, as we say here in India, *rupees*!

unnormalised: I was reading the other day about how even a small donation can make a huge difference. Like, seriously, just Rs. 500 can provide meals for a family in need for a week. Think about that! That's less than the cost of a fancy pizza! I mean, you can skip the Domino's for a week and make a real impact. It’s about prioritizing, right?
normalised: I was reading the other day about how even a small donation can make a huge difference. Like, seriously, just rupee five hundred can provide meals for a family in need for a week. Think about that! That's less than the cost of a fancy pizza! I mean, you can skip the Domino's for a week and make a real impact. It’s about prioritizing, right?

unnormalised: There are so many amazing charities out there doing incredible work. You've got ones focused on education, providing schoolbooks and uniforms for kids who can’t afford them. Think of organizations like CRY or Pratham. Even donating Rs 2000 can provide a scholarship to a deserving kid for a year! Then you have places like Helpage India working for the elderly. It's amazing how far your ₹s can stretch.
normalised: There are so many amazing charities out there doing incredible work. You've got ones focused on education, providing schoolbooks and uniforms for kids who can’t afford them. Think of organizations like C-R-Y or Pratham. Even donating rupee two thousand can provide a scholarship to a deserving kid for a year! Then you have places like Helpage India working for the elderly. It's amazing how far your rupees can stretch.

unnormalised: Plus, let's be honest, donating just *feels* good. You get that warm, fuzzy feeling inside knowing you’ve helped someone out. Maybe it’s the “karma” thing we Indians are all about, or maybe it’s just basic human decency. Whatever it is, it's a win-win. Like, I remember last Diwali, I donated ₹1000 to a local orphanage instead of buying myself that new saree I was eyeing. Best Diwali ever!
normalised: Plus, let's be honest, donating just *feels* good. You get that warm, fuzzy feeling inside knowing you’ve helped someone out. Maybe it’s the “karma” thing we Indians are all about, or maybe it’s just basic human decency. Whatever it is, it's a win-win. Like, I remember last Diwali, I donated rupee one thousand to a local orphanage instead of buying myself that new saree I was eyeing. Best Diwali ever!

unnormalised: Now, I know what you’re thinking: “I’m just a student/struggling professional/auto-rickshaw driver! I don’t have much to give.” But that’s the beauty of it! Every little bit counts. You don't need to donate 10,000 rupees. Even Rs. 100 can help. Maybe skip that overpriced coffee at Starbucks for a day (worth like ₹350!) and donate that money instead. Every rupee adds up, yaar!
normalised: Now, I know what you’re thinking: “I’m just a student slash struggling professional slash auto-rickshaw driver! I don’t have much to give.” But that’s the beauty of it! Every little bit counts. You don't need to donate ten thousand rupees. Even rupee one hundred can help. Maybe skip that overpriced coffee at Starbucks for a day (worth like rupee three hundred and fifty!) and donate that money instead. Every rupee adds up, yaar!

unnormalised: And don't forget about different ways to donate too. You don't have to just give cash. You can donate clothes, books, or even volunteer your time. A friend of mine volunteers at a local animal shelter every Saturday for 2 hrs. Or you can donate your old textbooks to that kid in your neighborhood who’s studying for their Class 10 boards. Every little bit matters.

unnormalised: So, yeah, just a little something to think about. Let's all try to give a little back, even if it’s just a few ₹s here and there. It’s good for the world, and it’s definitely good for the soul. What do you say, ready to spread some rupee-fueled happiness? :)
